Alertes_description:
...Warming Temperatures through Sunday...
There is a high potential for near record high temperatures
soaring into the upper 70s and 80s throughout the Panhandle
starting Thursday and continuing through Sunday. Friday will be
the warmest day with a greater than 80 percent chance of communities
seeing greater than 75 degrees. Warmest temperatures will occur
across the far southern Panhandle and communities located further
from coastal waters. There is a greater than 90 percent chance
that far southern communities such as Ketchikan and Hyder will
see temperatures greater than 80 degrees.
There will be some variability in high temperatures due to local
afternoon seabreezes and any low stratus that forms during the
overnight hours along coastal communities.
Remember, as temperatures warm and fuels become dry, there will
be an increased fire risk. To minimize impacts of the heat wave,
locate fans for cooling; wear light- colored and loose fitting
clothes; drink plenty of fluids, apply sun protection, and take
breaks if you must be outdoors for extended periods; do not leave
young children and pets unattended in closed vehicles; and plan to
check on the elderly, and neighbors who could be more vulnerable.

breezes ranging from 20-30 mph are also expected.

full, fast, and cold through this weekend. Mainly minor flooding
impacts are expected along the Walker River.
* Haze from the active Bone fire northwest of Yosemite National Park
will be possible across Alpine, northern Mono, and neighboring
counties in Nevada over the next couple days.

within the region may approach or exceed levels that are unhealthy
for sensitive groups.

with asthma, lung or heart disease, and older adults. Sensitive
children and adults should limit prolonged outdoor activity.
For additional information, please visit the Massachusetts
Department of Environmental Protection website at:
